annotations.justification: The speaker dismisses the utility of the current parliamentary system ('what is the benefit of staying in this politics'), questioning the legitimacy of the legislative process.
The speaker frames Maulana Fazlur Rehman as the 'only' politician with the credit of moving people from 'guns to ballots,' asserting moral and political dominance over all other Pakistani leaders.
The speaker issues a veiled threat that if the democratic path is closed, the party will be 'free to choose any path,' specifically mentioning 'revolution' (Inqilab) as an alternative to the ballot.
The speaker uses an 'either-or' framework: either the democratic way works as they demand, or they will opt for a totalizing 'revolution'.
Kundi dismisses the previous speaker's (Soomro) serious warnings of revolution as mere 'dialogues' or performance, trivializing the opponent's political stance.
The speaker uses the history of the Bhutto family's executions and assassinations to claim a higher moral status for the PPP compared to the JUI-F regarding democratic sacrifices.
The speaker portrays JUI-F as a party that inherently desires a 'dictator' and a repeat of the Musharraf-era 'MMA' alliance, framing them as anti-democratic opportunists.
The speaker characterizes the CM candidate (Ali Amin Gandapur) as a criminal involved in the May 9th riots whose 'crimes are forgiven' simply for being a candidate.
The speaker questions the fairness and consistency of the state's legal and judicial system regarding the May 9th cases.
The speaker explicitly denies the fairness of the elections in KPK, calling them not 'clean and transparent' (saaf-shaffaf).
The speaker separates 'those people' (PTI/Establishment beneficiaries) from the rest of the political victims, claiming they are above the law.
The speaker labels the opponent's claims as 'aerial firing' (empty talk/lies) and asserts that he only believes in 'proof,' positioning himself as a more credible actor.
The speaker uses demeaning language toward Sher Afzal Marwat ('Who are you? What is your status?'), attacking his personal standing and relevance.
The speaker completely denies Marwat's claim of contact with Zardari, calling him 'totally wrong' and accusing him of seeking self-importance.
The speaker uses highly insulting terms like 'maskharapan' (buffoonery/acting like a jester) and 'dramebaazi' (theatrics) to describe Marwat.
The speaker characterizes the opponent as 'not a serious person' and claims 'his game is over,' attempting to terminate his political legitimacy.
